description: From Late Latin ēvertere (“to turn (an item of clothing) inside out”), Latin ēvertere, present active infinitive of ēvertō (“to turn upside down; to overturn; to reverse”), from ē- (variant of ex- (prefix meaning ‘out, away’)) + vertō (“to reverse; to revolve, turn; to turn around”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *wert- (“to rotate, turn”)).

verbs.description: evert (third-person singular simple present everts, present participle everting, simple past and past participle everted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, often biology, physiology) To turn inside out (like a pocket being emptied) or outwards.
(transitive, obsolete) To move (someone or something) out of the way.
(transitive, obsolete, also figuratively) To turn upside down; to overturn.
(transitive, intransitive, obsolete, also figuratively) To disrupt; to overthrow.
